Ingardena 3, 30-060 Cracow (Poland) Abstract Normal-mode charge sensitivity analysis, based upon the semiempirical valence-shell hardness tensor in the atoms-in-molecules (AIM) resolution, has been applied to the V20o surface clusters, ranging from 1 to 6 pyramidal units, with the global number of electrons N corresponding to the net cluster charges (oxidation states) q varying from +4 to -4. The AIM charges used to model the hardness tensor are from the semiempirical SCF MO calculations in the S (scaled) INDO approximation. The new phase convention for the populational normal modes (directions of the tensor principal axes) is introduced via the requirement oa - aN/a vq > 0 for all charge transfer (CT) active modes, where va is the collective electron population coordinate associated with the mode a. Namely, the equilibrium electron population displacements are strongly localized on a small subset of the CT active modes, with only very few such modes significantly contributing to the AIM Fukui function (FF) indices [ 1,57]: {Fj - aN;/aN} =F (4 ) where N=E;N; is the global number of electrons. The AIM FF indices themselves already constitute a useful site selectivity criterion for nucleophilic/ electrophilic attacks by small reactants [ 1,4,6-9 ] . The same information follows from the shapes and other characteristics of the normal modes [ 1,5-7 ] ; the charge sensitivity data for chemisorbed systems may in turn be used to qualitatively predict the directions of the desorption and dissociation processes [ 5-7 ] . The normal mode representation also provides an attractive framework for examining the mode-to-mode donor/acceptor interactions between large reactants [ 1,2 ] . Previous CSA applications to oxide catalysts were limited to a single global number of electrons in a cluster [ 5-7 ] . Our preliminary results for vanadium oxide clusters [6] have been obtained for an idealized, model AIM charges, while a more refined calculations for the rutile clusters [ 7 ] have used the SCF MO [S(symmetrically orthogonalized) INDO] charges. It is the main purpose of the present work to examine how the normal mode description of the vanadium oxide model surface clusters is affected by changing N (or the cluster overall oxidation state q). In particular we examine how the onset of the softest mode charge instability, marked by the negative lowest eigenvalue ha (a=1), manifests itself in selected normal mode characteristics. We also introduce a new phase convention, fixing the directions of the hardness tensor principal ages, which allows one to distinguish the acceptor vs. donor normal modes, using the signs of the normal FF indices, R.F Nalewajski and J. Calculations and results The details of the model clusters of the (010) V205 monolayer surface have been given elsewhere [ 6 ] . Also the S (scaled) INDO [ 13 ] SCF MO energies have already been reported previously [ 12 ] . Catal. 82 (1993) 383-405 reservoir or the reaction partner) then only second-order energy changes of the corresponding Taylor expansion of the cluster energy, represent the internal charge reorganization contributions. Therefore, when f is dominated by the softest mode, ha ;:t: 0, the charge reorganization within a cluster, due to CT, can be effected practically at constant energy (strong polarizability, soft AIM electron distribution). The opposite situation arises when f exhibits large components from hard modes (weak polarizability, hard AIM electron distribution). While the large soft mode contributions are exceptional for the chargestable energy surfaces, large components of such modes in equilibrium displacements on the charge-unstable surfaces become a rule. In the charge instability region some normal FF indices can exhibit large magnitude when the f vector is close to the respective principal axis directions (see Fig. 1). In such cases the wa and fa quantities indicate both stabilizing and destabilizing contributions to ECT (positive and negative contributions to NCT, respectively), as seen, e.g., in Fig. 4 for N> 35 (see also Fig. 6), in the 1 pyramid cluster. In the 2 pyramid case (Fig. 9) the negative w factors are observed also when the energy surface becomes mode unstable, i.e., for N 63. As a general rule one observes the growing importance of the softest CTactive modes with increasing degree of reduction of a cluster (compare wa entries in the first column of Fig. 6) . At the same time the participation of the hardest mode in the equilibrium charge displacements diminishes (compare the wa quantities in the third column of Fig. 6 ). Another example can be seen in the 2 pyramid case. Namely, in Fig. 9 for N= 67 (q = - 3) the largest stabilizing wa > 0 comes from the softest mode a =1, while for N= 61 (q = 3) the stabilizing contribution from the hardest a= 11 mode dominates. (23) these diagrams also represent a resolution of the AIM FF pattern of Fig. 8 into the normal mode contributions. It follows from Fig. 10 that only modes a = (1, 3) significantly contribute to the equilibrium charge displacements of the cluster. This concentration of {w;,} quantities in a very few modes has also been observed previously [ 1,6,7 ] . This mode localization effect clearly shows the physical importance of the normal mode reference frame; it greatly facilitates qualitative discussion of CT processes within the mode-resolved picture. AIM FF indices The evolution of the AIM FF distributions with a growing cluster size and changing oxidation states is shown in Figs. 5, 8, 11, 12, and 13. Such local charge sensitivities provide a direct information about local donor/acceptor behaviour of AIM within a cluster, and therefore they can serve as reactivity criteria in predicting site selectivities towards an electrophilic/nucleophilic attack.[ 1,4,6,7 ] . R.F Nalewajski and J. Korchowiec/J Mol. Catal. 82 (1993) 383-405 403 It follows from Fig. 5 that for dN> 0 (nucleophilic attack, cluster acts as an acid) the inflowing charge for N < 36 goes mainly to the vanadyl oxygen O ( 1 ); at the same time one observes a growing negative F; value at the vanadium atom with increasing cluster reduction. Since the F; < 0 site should strengthen the coordination from the nucleophile to the cluster, the vanadium atom is predicted as the preferred site for a nucleophilic attack; for N> 36 the pattern changes, with the O ( 1 ) atom being identified as the preferred site in such strongly reduced clusters. A similar qualitative change in the AIM FF distribution, accompanying the increasing N, can be observed in Fig. 8. For high oxidation states the vanadium atoms exhibit F; < 0, thus representing the most probable locations of a nucleophilic attack; for N> 62 the bridging oxygen 0(2) is seen as the preferred site for such a coordination (with the N=67 distribution being an exception to this rule). These observations demonstrate how strongly the reactivity indices of catalytic oxide clusters depend upon their oxidation (reduction) state. A further support for this general conclusion comes from the remaining {F;} plots. For example, as seen in Fig. 11, the vanadium atom of the central pyramid should preferably coordinate a nucleophilic adsorbate for N= 78 (q=3 ). For higher N values a common pattern emerges with the bridging 0(2) atoms (and to a lower degree O (3 ) atom) being identified as the preferred sites. A similar conclusion follows from a comparison of Figs. 12 and 13: the O (2 oxygens are seen to be definitely preferred as sites for nucleophilic coordination. We would like to point out that for some values of N the F; indices reach very large magnitudes (marked by small scaling factors in parentheses). For example, the amplitudes for N= (60, 63 and 67) in Fig. 8 appear as relatively large. In the 1 pyramid cluster the large F; values are observed only for negative clusters. In Fig. 11 strong catalytic activity may be predicted for the q = 2 case, as witnessed by the value of scaling factor which is ten times lower relative to the remaining cases. For the 4 pyramid cluster the q=0 charge displacements are basically twice as large as those observed for the q=-2 case. Another dramatic example of such large displacements of AIM charges is also seen in Fig. 13 (6 pyramids) for N=148 (q = 2) . Concluding remarks We have supplemented in this study the AIM resolved CSA by the new phase convention in the normal representation, which identifies the modes acting as acceptors or donors of electrons directly from the sign of the normal FF index (or that of the wa energetical weight); this is analogous to the AIM representation description. Since, as we have already demonstrated previously, the f and w vectors are dominated by components from a very few CT-active modes, one can interpret CT processes in terms of equilibrium displacements along these (usually 1 or 2) physically the most important populational de- 404 RE Nalewajski and J. Korchowiec/J. Mol. Catal. 82 (1993) 383-405 grees of freedom of the system under consideration. Such an interplay between a few modes should facilitate qualitative predictions of both site- and pathselectivities of CT reactions. It should also constitute an adequate basis for formulating hypotheses about how to manipulate the system (or its environment), in order to activate the system towards the desired reaction path, or speed up a given CT reaction. Our present comparison between the CSA and SCF MO global predictions clearly demonstrate a surprising consistency between the electronegativity and hardness data for changing overall oxidation state of the vanadium oxide clusters, with the onset of the system charge instability appearing after passing the minimum of the SCF energy curve E(N). We have shown, however, that the E" (N) surfaces exhibit saddle points at less reduced states of the cluster. Thus, should the direction of the initial charge displacement of the system be modified to go along a given unstable normal mode (ha < 0 ), the system would then spontaneously rearrange its charge in accordance with the mode topology. Such modification of the direction of f vector could be realized, e.g., by modifying the cluster environment, e.g., the catalyst support. The knowledge of the charge-unstable modes should provide a solid basis for a theoretical modeling of the surface clusters towards the desired catalytic activity. It has already been argued elsewhere [1,7,10] that the CSA provides a relatively simple and fast diagnostic tool for discussing the reaction paths which are possible when the constraint of the constant N in the reactive system is lifted; we call such processes the N-unrestricted reactions. Clearly, they can be run only when the reactive system is only a part of a larger, e.g., macroscopic system as is the case with the catalytic active centres. The N-free paths may involve lower activation barriers in the electron population space, relative to the N-restricted reaction paths [ 7,10 ] . We believe that exploration of the Nfree paths in catalytic reactions would give additional insight into the role played by the surface environment/support. It should also offer an interesting new perspective for theoretical rationalization of the principles of hard/soft acids and bases [ 15 ] . The present study also illustrates the experimentally known strong dependence of the catalytic activity on the degree of oxidation/reduction of active centres. As we have seen the pattern of the AIM FF indices, or equivalently contours of the crucial normal modes, exhibit quite substantial changes with N (q). Our analysis identifies the oxidation states for which the catalytic activity should be particularly strong. The FF distributions reported in the present study, based on realistic SCF MO charges, differ in various aspects from those calculated for a more uniformly distributed model AIM charges of the previous analysis [ 6 ] . We have seen, however, that the bridging oxygens O (2 emerge as the preferred sites for nucleophilic attacks, in general agreement with the previous theoretical conjectures [6,12]. R.F. Normal-mode charge sensitivity analysis, based upon the semiempirical valence-shell hardness tensor in the atoms-in-molecules (AIM) resolution, has been applied to the V2O5 surface clusters, ranging from 1 to 6 pyramidal units, with the global number of electrons N corresponding to the net cluster charges (oxidation states) q varying from + 4 to −4. The AIM charges used to model the hardness tensor are from the semiempirical SCF MO calculations in the S (scaled) INDO approximation. The new phase convention for the populational normal modes (directions of the tensor principal axes) is introduced via the requirement φα. ≡ ∂N / ∂υα > 0 for all charge transfer (CT) active modes, where υ α is the collective electron population coordinate associated with the mode α. This convention allows one to identify the modes exhibiting the donor/acceptor behaviour opposite to the global basic/acidic characteristic of the system, as those corresponding to the negative normal Fukui function (FF) index, ⨍α ≡ ∂υα / ∂N < 0, similarly to the familiar AIM description. The q-dependence of the AIM and normal FF indices, as well as that of shapes and selected characteristics of the CT active normal modes, are examined with a special emphasis on the charge instability region, where the principal hardness, h α ≡ ∂μα/∂υα, of the softest mode (α = 1) becomes negative and the global hardness η ≡ ∂2 E /∂N 2 < 0; here E denotes the system electronic energy and μα is the mode chemical potential: μα ≡ ∂E/∂υα. The compared quantities include: h α, φα, ⨍α, χα = −μα, and the product w α = φα⨍α reflecting the mode energy contribution in units of the overall CT energy. The pattern of reactivity indices is shown to be strongly dependent on the cluster oxidation/reduction state.
